sentence-detokenized: FOOTBALL - JAPAN WINS A LUCKY VICTORY, CHINA SUFFERS AN UNEXPECTED DEFEAT.
Japan began the defense of its Asian championship title with a 2-1 victory over Syria in a Group C match on Friday.
But in the second match of the group, the luck turned away from China, and it suffered an unexpected defeat from the newcomer Uzbekistan with a score of 2:0.

China controlled most of the match and missed several chances until the 78th minute, when Uzbek striker Igor Shkvirin took advantage of an errant defensive header and flipped the ball over the advancing Chinese goalkeeper into the empty net.
The victory in stoppage time was scored by Oleg Shatsku, who struck an irresistible left footed shot from outside the penalty area.
The former Soviet republic played in the Asian Cup final for the first time.
Despite the fact that two years ago Uzbekistan won the title of the winner of the Asian Games, they are outsiders in the final.
Two goals from defensive errors in the last six minutes allowed Japan to take the lead and take all three points from the opening game against Syria.

Takuya Takagi scored the winning goal in the 88th minute, rising to Hiroshige Yanagimoto's pass towards the Syrian goal, which goalkeeper Salem Bitar seemed to cover, but then allowed the ball to slip into the net.
This was Syria's second costly blunder in four minutes.
In the 84th minute, defender Hassan Abbas rose to intercept a long ball into the area, but only managed to redirect it into the top corner of the Bitar goal.
Nader Jokhadar put Syria ahead with an accurate header in the seventh minute.
Japan then laid siege to the Syrian penalty area for most of the game, but rarely broke through the Syrian defense.
Bitar made great saves every time they arose.
Japan coach Shu Kamo said: "The Syrian own goal was lucky for us.
The Syrians scored early and then played defensively, taking long balls, which made it difficult for us. '
Japan, which hosted the World Cup in 2002 and is ranked 20th in the world by FIFA, is the favorite to regain its title at this tournament.
On Saturday in the matches of Group A, the hosts of the tournament UAE host Kuwait, and South Korea - Indonesia.
All four teams have one point from one game.
RUGBY UNION - CATTITTA RETURNED TO ITALY IN A YEAR.
on Friday for a friendly against Scotland at Murrayfield more than a year after the 30-year-old flanker announced he was retiring following a disagreement over selection.
Cattitta, who coach George Costa said was certain to play on Saturday, was included in a 21-man squad missing only two from the team that beat England 54-21 at Twickenham last month.
Stefano Bordon is out through illness and Coste said he started Corrado Covi, who was recalled for the England game after five years away from the national team.
Cuttitta announced his retirement after the 1995 World Cup, where he expressed his dissatisfaction with being dropped from the Italian national team, which met England in the knockout stage.
Koste said that he had contacted the player two months ago about his return.
"He ended the World Cup on the wrong note," Coste said.
"I thought it would be useful if he came back and he said he would be free.
I think now is the right time for his return. "

The squad: Javier Pertile, Paolo Vaccari, Marcello Cuttitta, Ivan Francescato, Leandro Manteri, Diego Dominguez, Francesco Mazzariol, Alessandro Troncon, Orazio Aranzio, Andrea Sgorlon, Massimo Giovanelli, Carlo Cecchinato, Walter Cristofoletto, Franco Properzi Curti, Carlo Orlandi, Massimo Cuttitta, Giambattista Croci, Gianluca Guidi, Nicola Mazzucato, Alessandro Moscardi, Andrea Castellani.
SOCCER - LATE GOALS GIVE JAPAN VICTORY OVER SYRIA.
Two goals in the last six minutes gave hosts Japan a disappointing 2-1 win over Syria in the Asian Cup on Friday.
Takuya Takagi put the winners ahead in the 88th minute of the Group C match after goalkeeper Salem Bitar spoiled an unmistakable pass, allowing the ball to slip under his body.
It was the second miss of the Syrian defense in four minutes.
In the 84th minute, defender Hassan Abbas rose to intercept a long ball into the area, but only managed to redirect it into the top corner of the Bitar goal.
Syria took the lead with the first serious attack in the seventh minute.
Nader Jokhadar headed a cross from the right by Ammar Awad into the top right corner of Kenichi Shimokawa's goal.
Then Japan besieged the Syrian penalty area and in the 16th minute scored a goal due to offside.
A minute later, Bitar made a great double save, first deflecting Kazuyoshi Miura's header and then blocking Takagi's shot.
In the 37th minute Bitar again saved from Miura's shot, deflecting his header from a corner.
Japan made a bright start to the second half but Bitar denied them an equaliser when he dived to his right and saved Naoki Soma's shot in the 53rd minute.

FOOTBALL - THE BAN ON FLASHING LIGHTS WAS ABOLISHED.
Dutch forward Reggie Blinker was suspended by FIFA on Friday and was due to play on Saturday against Liverpool in the match against Sheffield Wednesday.
Blinker missed his club's last two games after FIFA imposed a worldwide ban on him for turning up at the signings of Wednesday and Udinese when he was playing for Feyenoord.
The FIFA Committee on the status of players, which met in Barcelona, decided that although Udinese's document is valid in principle, it cannot be legally protected.
The Committee stated that the Italian club violated the regulations without informing Feyenoord, with whom the player was under contract.
Blinker was fined 75,000 Swiss francs (57,600 USD) for failing to inform the English club of his previous commitment to Udinese.
FOOTBALL - LEEDS BOWYER FINED FOR PARTICIPATING IN A FIGHT IN FAST FOOD.
English Leeds Under-21 striker Lee Bauer was fined £4,500 ($7,400) on Friday for throwing chairs at restaurant staff during a riot at a McDonald's fast food restaurant.
Bower, 19, who was caught at the scene by CCTV, pleaded guilty to a charge of trespassing at a court in London.
It was fined and ordered to pay £175 compensation to two employees who were injured during an altercation at the east London restaurant in October.
Leeds have already fined Bowyer £4,000 ($6,600) and warned him that repeating his criminal behaviour could cost him a place in the side.
Bauer, who joined the Yorkshire club in August for £3.5 million ($5.8 million), is expected to play against Middlesbrough on Saturday.

RUGBY UNION - FEW WILL MISS THE FAREWELL TO CAMPING.
Centre Jason Little will miss Australia's final round match against the Barbarians at Twickenham on Saturday.
Little decided not to risk aggravating the knee injury that has seen him miss most of the tour and will be replaced by Queenslander Daniel Herbert.
Owen Finegan recovered from a knock sustained in last weekend's Test against Wales and retained his place in the back row ahead of Daniel Manu.

"The Wallabies are targeting a 13th straight win to complete their European tour with a 100 per cent record, but they also want to turn on the style and give David Campis a fitting send-off in his last match in Australian colours.

The Wallabies are not currently planning any special celebrations for the 34-year-old winger, but a full house of 75,000 spectators will still gather in the hope of witnessing one last moment of magic.
Campes will face a familiar opponent in Barbarians captain Rob Andrew, the man who handed Australia defeat with a last-minute goal in the quarter-finals of the World Cup in Cape Town.
"Campo has a huge following in this country and the public have supported him since he first played here in 1984," said Andrew, who is also likely to make his last appearance at Twickenham.
On the tour, Australia won all four matches against Italy, Scotland, Ireland and Wales, scoring 414 points, an average of almost 35 points per game.

League commitments have limited the Barbarians' selection options but they still boast 13 foreigners, including England full-back Tim Stimpson and recalled flanker Tony Underwood, as well as All Blacks forwards Ian Jones and Norm Hewitt.

FOOTBALL - PLAYERS WITHOUT CAPS ARE CALLED FOR THE MATCH WITH MACEDONIA.
Romanian national team coach Angel Iordanescu called up three unprotected players to his squad on Friday, which will face Macedonia next week in a World Cup qualifier.

Midfielder Valentin Stefan and striker Viorel Ion from Ocelul Galati and defender Liviu Ciobotariu from National Bucharest are the newcomers to the European Eight, who will take the field on December 14 in Macedonia.
Iordanescu said he chose them because of their good performances in the domestic championship, in which National Bucharest is ranked first and Otelul Galati third. "
I think it will be fair to give them a chance," he told reporters.
The Champions League champion Steaua Bucharest, which took the last place in its Champions League group in the European Cup, has only two players in its squad.
Attacking midfielder Adrian Ilie, who recently moved from Steaua to Turkish Galatasaray, was sent off after two yellow cards.
Defenders - Dan Petrescu, Daniel Prodan, Anton Dobos, Cornel Papura, Liviu Ciobotariu, Tibor Selimes, Iulian Filipescu.

CRICKET - LARA IS HAVING ANOTHER MISERABLE DAY.
Australia gave Brian Lara another reason to be unhappy as they beat the West Indies by five wickets in the opening match of the limited overs World Series on Friday.
Lara, punished on Wednesday for misconduct, was suspended for five days to continue a disappointing streak on tour.
Australia, who lead 2-0 in the five-match Test series, bowled out the West Indies for a total of 172 with eight balls to spare, ending a run of six consecutive one-day defeats.
All-rounder Greg Blewett led his team to a comfortable victory with an unbeaten 57 off 90 balls to the delight of 42,442 spectators.
Man of the Match Blewett took the wicket at 70 for two and hit three fours in a trouble-free innings that lasted 129 minutes.
His crucial fifth wicket partnership with fellow all-rounder Stuart Law, who scored 21, added 71 off 85 balls.
Lara looked lost during his brief stay at the crease before chipping a simple delivery to Shane Warne at mid-wicket.
West Indies tour manager Clive Lloyd apologized for Lara's behavior on Tuesday.
He (Lara) told the coach of the Australian national team Geoff Marsh that it is undesirable for goalkeeper Ian Healy to be in the dressing room of the visitors.
The Melbourne crowd were clearly outraged by the incident, loudly jeering the West Indies vice-captain as he walked to the centre.
His left-handed counterpart Shivnarine Chanderpaul, despite a groin injury, batted until the end of the innings with a score of 54.
Chanderpaul has been forced to rely on a runner for the majority of his innings after he was injured when he rushed back to his crease to avoid a runner.
Pakistan, which will arrive in Australia later this month, is the second team participating in the World Series tournament.

CRICKET - LARA SUFFERS EVEN MORE FROM THE AUSTRALIAN TOUR.

West Indies batsman Brian Lara has suffered another blow to his Australian tour, after he was already punished for misconduct when he was cheaply removed in the first limited overs match against Australia on Friday.
Lara, who received a stern rebuke from his own tour management after an outburst of anger against Australia wicketkeeper Ian Healy, scored five to continue a run of poor form with the bat.
The West Indies vice-captain was struggling for time during his 36-minute stay at the crease before he deflected a ball off medium pacer Tom Moody straight to Shane Warne at mid-wicket.
The West Indies were 53 for two in 15 overs when rain halted play at the Melbourne Cricket Ground after captain Courtney Walsh won the toss and was selected to bat.
Lara's case three days ago clearly turned part of the Australian public against him.
When he approached the gate, he was met with loud shouts from some parts of the crowd.
Several times during his pitches the crowd united in a series of obscene shouts at him.

Tour manager Clive Lloyd on Wednesday apologised for the behaviour of Lara, who clashed with Australia coach Geoff Marsh in the opposition dressing room to protest his dismissal in Tuesday's second Test.
Lloyd did not say what form this discipline would take.

Lara, who holds the record for highest wicket-taker in Test and first-class cricket, was unhappy with Healy's role in the incident and questioned whether the ball had reached the Australian wicketkeeper.
Australia won the match at the Sydney Cricket Stadium by 124 runs to take a 2-0 lead in the five-match series after Lara failed in both innings.
Lara has not yet turned a century since the West Indies arrived in Australia five weeks ago.
The leadership of the West Indies and Australian teams downplayed the incident, stressing that relations between the two sides were not negatively affected.
Pakistan, which arrives next week, is the third team in the triangular World Series tournament.
CRICKET - WEST INDIES BAT AFTER WINNING THE TOSS.
West Indies captain Courtney Walsh was selected to bat after winning the toss in the first limited overs World Series match against Australia at the Melbourne Cricket Ground on Friday.
